Article.ArticleTitle: Hybrid reactor based on hydrodynamic cavitation, ozonation, and persulfate oxidation for oxalic acid decomposition during rare-earth extraction processes.

AbstractText: A cost-effective method for treating oxalic acid (OA) during rare-earth extraction was developed using hydrodynamic cavitation (HC), ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), and persulfate (PS) (HC@PS@O<sub>3</sub> process). The results showed that the optimal inlet pressure during HC was 5.10 kg cm<sup>-2</sup> with an orifice plate diameter of 2 mm. Moreover, HC was shown to activate PS, providing an alternative activation method to base or heat as an ultrasound activation method for chemical oxidation. O<sub>3</sub> was also shown to activate PS. For OA oxidation using the HC@PS@O<sub>3</sub> process, the optimum pH was 3 and the reaction rate increased with increasing temperature. Further, the activation energy was 36.69 kJ mol<sup>-1</sup>. The mechanisms unveiled in this study will allow optimization of the HC@PS@O<sub>3</sub> process as a chemical oxidation technology. The kinetic investigation and economic evaluation of the HC@PS@O<sub>3</sub> process can be used as the basis for real wastewater treatment processes in the future.
